Examinations.—There are three departments of college preparatory education—primary, middle and high. The last two are usually united under the name "secondary." All
departmental examinations in the primary department are conducted by the educational department through inspectors and assistant inspectors. In this department there are three
examinations, on the basis of which aided
schools earn grants, namely: infant, third primary and fifth primary.
The middle school and matriculation examinations are conducted in various centres by the
University, which sets the papers, appoints examiners thereof, and, of course, collects examination fees from the examiners. The same
method obtains in the three higher examinations, for F. A., B. A., and M. A.
For the primary school, the Educational Department decides both the text-books and the
standard of each class, while in the secondary
and collegiate departments the University is allpowerful, and decides text-books and standard,
while at the same time using the Educational
Department as an advisory colleague.
Defects and Problems.-1. The system of
having examiners who are out of touch with
the students and are more or less irresponsible,
is a cold-blooded one and often works injustice.
Sir Arthur Havelock, Lieutenant-Governor of
Madras, in a comparatively recent speech, indicated that in his opinion true progress would
be towards a teaching university.
2. The cramming system reigns in all its
glory, to the exclusion of true education. After
fighting against the system in India, it is disappointing to find the inroads it has been making in America. It gets first into normal
schools here, it would seem, and then a little
later the ordinary pupil has to suffer.

3. The attempt to give an education in Government schools which should be religiously
colorless has not been fruitful of good. The
Director of Public Instruction of Bengal called
attention to this matter last year. Old ties have
been broken and nothing new takes its place.
There is need of more moral teaching, and if
that means religion, Government must not be
afraid of it.

The exhibition, on the whole, was interesting, but there are some points which admit of
great improvement, and should be borne in
mind for future guidance and help. In the
first place, the programme was too long, and,
as the exercises did not begin until after 8.30
o'clock, things began to get tiresome before the
exhibition was over.
The greatest point which ought to be spoken
of is the fact that the exhibition did not fulfill
its purpose. This purpose was to show to the
public the best gymnastic talent of the University, while, in reality, the older men who were
experienced and proficient in the exercises were
engaged in lacrosse, baseball or track training,
and the exhibition was carried on by the comparatively new men. In this sense, the exhibition was not representative of the best talent
of the University. There is no doubt that had
the event been held in January or February,
as was formerly the custom, when no outdoor
training was in progress, the best athletes that
Hopkins affords could have been had to make
the exhibition a far greater success. Old students here say that the events held back in the

DR. WARREN'S DEPARTURE.

It has been generally known for some time
that Dr. Minton Warren has been considering
a call to the American School of Classical
Studies at Rome, but the news of his acceptance of a professorship at Harvard came as a
surprise to all but a few of his most intimate
associates. Dr. Warren has been connected
with the University for nearly twenty years,
and, during that time, has achieved a reputation throughout Europe and America. He is
a graduate of Tufts College, and received the
degree of Ph. D.from the University of Strassburg. Two years ago he held the position of

director of the American School at Rome. At
Hopkins he has, through his personal popularity and distinguished scholarship, built up a
department which is rightly recognized as one
of the strongest connected with the University.
His successor has not yet been announced.
Dr. Warren is the first head of a department
who has accepted a call elsewhere since the
foundation of the University. In his position
at Harvard he will be the successor of the late
Professor Lane, whose death occurred about
two years ago.
Dr. Franklin of the Baltimore Evening News
made Professor Warren's departure the subject of an editorial a few days ago. He once
more emphasized the University's pressing
need of additional gifts to provide against the
always possible loss of others from that group
of scholars who have given Johns Hopkins the
pre-eminent reputation which it bears.

John H. Finley, a graduate student of Johns
Hopkins University, from October, 1887, to
February, 1889, and for several years past
(1893-1899) President of Knox College,
Galesburg, Illinois, has recently been appointed editor of McClure's Magazine. He is the
fifth Johns Hopkins man to become prominently identified with leading monthlies, the
others being his brother R. J. Finley, Walter
H. Page, editor of the Atlantic Monthly, and
formerly of The Forum, Albert Shaw, editor
of the American Review of Reviews, and
Charles I). Lanier, of the same magazine.
Robert J. Finley, the brother of the newly
appointed editor, was for some years editorially connected with the American Review of
Reviews, and at the time of his death was the
manager of an extensive syndicate for supplying leading newspapers of this country with
articles and information on current subjects.
The Finley brothers were both in the Historical Department of the Johns Hopkins University, and at one time were both engaged
in managing' the so-called "Newspaper Bureau," a kind of department clearing-house
for student information on current politics.

to be posted by Shaw and Robert Finley on
bulletin boards around the walls of the old

The baseball team has essayed more
ambitious work this season than for some
years past. After making a highly creditable
showing against the picked sons of Old Nassau, the team faced the heavy hitters of the National League on April 13, in the shape of the
Baltimore baseball team.
This game was intended simply to give practice to the men, and no one expected that the
Baltimores would do anything but wipe up the
field with their opponents. If we could do as
well, or nearly as well, as the University of
Maryland had done on the day before, we
would be satisfied. Overwhelming defeat,
even at the hands of such players as the Orioles, would be no disgrace.
The result of this game, while not particularly edifying, was, on the whole, satisfactory.
The men did not show that nervousness and
generally rattled condition that was so evident
in the Princeton game. In one inning, however, the work was very ragged. When a runner was coming home on a steal or an error,
the man with the ball did not seem to know
where to throw it, and the whole field was
thrown into confusion. Strouse committed
an error here which he should take care to
avoid in the future. When the ball was being
thrown in •to the catcher, he would invariably
attempt to head it off, allowing several men
to bring in runs meanwhile.
Strouse pitched a good game, but he should
not allow himself to be discouraged whenever
he is batted heavily. When an inexperienced
freshman pitcher faces a League team, he
should think himself fortunate in lasting
through the first inning. Strouse's work so
. far this season has been excellent.
The encouraging effect of this game was
seen in the vim and dash with which the team
tackled Washington College on the 15th.
Townsend, the Eastern Shore pitcher, struck
out eighteen men during the game, but with
all that, he was hit freely, and 17 runs were
made. The Hopkins men showed a great im-

provement over their previous playing, and
with such batting and fielding as they did then,
they should have a strong show for the intercollegiate championship.
The game with St. John's was simply a batting picnic. We hit their pitcher all over the
field at will, Joyner, Clarke, Swaine and
Downes getting three hits apiece. The fielding was a good object-lesson of the improvement that has been made since the beginning
of the season. Almost a perfect record was
made, some of the chances accepted being
very difficult. It is a strange coincidence that
the score of this game was also 17 to 6.
The baseball team this year is the best that
we have had for several seasons, and it should
receive better support than it has heretofore.
It does not seem that the baseball team is
being justly treated by either the athletic association or the university at large. Because
previous teams have been of such a character
as to shed little glory upon the institution, it is
not right, on that account, to condemn baseball entirely. The team was on the point of
'disbanding early in the season owing to lack
of support, but they determined to stick it out,
and hope for the best. If they win the pennant, it will be additional honor to the men
that they have persevered and won in the face
of discouraging- circumstances.

HOPKINS 20, HARVARD 0

Fair Harvard, the home of so many champion athletic teams, suffered a very severe
shock Saturday afternoon, to the tune of an
overwhelming defeat at the hands of our team,
by a score of 20 to 0.
The large crowd present, attracted by Harvard's fame and by the work of our lacrosse
management naturally hoped for a victory for
the Black and the Blue, but in their most sanguine moments Hopkins rooters dared hope
for nc4 such success as was won. Not even
Manila bay, with its score of eleven Spanish
ships to nothing, was as decisive as the recent
skirmish at Union Park. The game itself

having examiners who are out of touch with
the students and are more or less irresponsible,
is a cold-blooded one and often works injustice.
Sir Arthur Havelock, Lieutenant-Governor of
Madras, in a comparatively recent speech, indicated that in his opinion true progress would

glory, to the exclusion of true education. After
fighting against the system in India, it is disappointing to find the inroads it has been making in America. It gets first into normal
schools here, it would seem, and then a little
later the ordinary pupil has to suffer.

colorless has not been fruitful of good. The
Director of Public Instruction of Bengal called
attention to this matter last year. Old ties have
been broken and nothing new takes its place.
There is need of more moral teaching, and if

two years ago.
